paragraph: A similar motive is found in the “Deluge” of Rubens (in the Munich Art Gallery), where a serpent emasculates a man. This motive explains the meaning of the “Deluge”; the maternal sea is also the devouring mother.[853] The phantasy of the world conflagration, of the cataclysmic end of the world in general, is nothing but a mythological projection of a personal individual will for death; therefore, Rubens could represent the essence of the “Deluge” phantasy in the emasculation by the serpent; for the serpent is our own repressed will for the end, for which we find an explanation only with the greatest difficulty.Concerning the symbolism of the serpent in general, its significance is very dependent upon the time of life and circumstances. The repressed sexuality of youth is symbolized by the serpent, because the arrival of sexuality puts an end to childhood. To age, on the contrary, the serpent signifies the repressed thought of death. With our author it is the insufficiently expressed sexuality which as serpent assumes the rôle of sacrificer and delivers the hero over to death and rebirth.
question: What does the serpent symbolize for the author in terms of sexual repression and its relation to the hero's journey?
answer: For the author in the context of the "Deluge" painting, the serpent symbolizes the insufficiently expressed sexuality, which takes on the role of a sacrificer. The serpent delivers the hero to death and rebirth, reflecting the complex interplay between sexual repression and the transformative process of the hero's journey. This symbol highlights the psychological and mythological significance of the serpent in driving the hero towards a resolution of repressed desires.
